season farmer but for them they need to go into greater detail and understand the why the why i'm doing it why am i coming in with this type of land preparation why should i also control weeds within the first six to eight weeks why is this insect pest a problem and how can i manage it before it reaches levels where it's going to reduce my yields so all of these things they come into play for a in their friends to just drive around the field and and not go inside the field to check otherwise some of these problematic diseases barley they start from inside the field then spread outwards so if amongst us the past uh three to five years we have seen a lot of unforeseen weather burglaries that have been going on where you find that in some instances it's a false start to the season where you think the season is started it's october well ending end it's uh mid october when the season usually starts you get rains for three days then it goes for two weeks without raining three weeks or a month so that that will be a false start then you get a premature termination of the season mid-season dry spells that prolong for example um in zim we had about four weeks with no rain in february which is not a norm so some of these changes are also uh things that have caused in red havoc amongst our farmers in terms of their uh operation and yes are talking about the heavy rains as well because the misconception that is they ball is that climate change is associated with no rain or drought but climate change just means that the norm what we are used to has been shifted or changed a bit so heavy rains also go into climate change and the heavy rains that were experienced in south africa in mozambique the rays that the persistent rains that we received in zim we got persistent rains and a bit of flooding in some instances so those scenarios the farmer would not have prepared for because according to the weather forecast which is the main guide that provides information into what this isn't going to be like they don't get to see some of these um scenarios in advance maybe they get to see them three to five days before they're okay but that means the farmer is ready if it's planting planted but then if the rain's coming and they are heavy that crop is going to be swept off and if the uh the farmer has already planted their crop and did not do maybe some conservation agriculture principles or water management drainage system uh principles you find that flooding may also occur in the field so it's difficult to really plan for climate change the best we can do is to mitigate the effects how so you need to then understand uh from the guidance that you get from the meteorological services department which is the one which is um which governs and understands the climatic issues that face that are going to be characteristic of that season if they tell you that you're expecting a number to above normal rainfall then the three to five day focus are the regular guides that you need to be uh partaking in if you know that maybe your area is prone to flooding then you come in with contour ridges you come in with um drainage inside the field so that the water gets to wash off and not uh flood inside the fields if it's an area that tends to be dry drier than other areas then you know that water is important you also need to come in with your port hauling your chai bridges different uh practices that are going to conserve as much moisture as possible mulching all those principles need to come in so i would say we have seen a lot of uh disgruntlement uh amongst our farmers both commercial and communal where even for the commercial farmer in some instances even when they think they want to irrigate they don't get enough rain to fill their water bodies so irrigation is also then affected then the communal farmer thinks that uh maybe since i have done um i've done my my ca my conservation agriculture uh there's minimum soil disturbance and oh when the rains come in they're still come in and they flood the field because there's no deep speculation of the water into the ground so it's not easy for our farmers really climate change it's not easy for us as well as an industry whereby we are also tasked with availing uh crops that are also tolerant to some of these challenges that might be faced be it the the the prolonged dry spell you need a drought tolerant variety that is going to remain maybe at a particular stage for a certain time and then come back and resume growth when the conditions are allowing and then you also need maybe earliness a variety that matures earlier so that it escapes the effects of of climate change by by maturing before the dry spell commences so there is a lot that the industry is trying to do to long time on the market and they've been farmer retained it's like the seed that the farmer is going to return over and over and over again but uh initially it was enough for you to have that seed because that was in the advent of agriculture and as a technology it was a good technology for us to have those language varieties but over time as you know that agriculture is not constant it's also dynamic like any other sector over time it was realized that the yields that are obtained from opv's open pollinated varieties or farm saved varieties over years they they tend to be lower compared to the need that was arising from the increase in population that was being experienced so there was a need for us to reach food security and food security then feeds into food surplus for us to then export to our other countries that might still be in need so as africa we have not really mastered the um the ability to produce what is enough for ourselves enough for us to then sell to other countries so there was a need a gap there that existed that then prompted breeders to come in with what we are turning hybrid seed because with hybrid seeds now you are now getting more value out of the same amount of seeds that you will have established for example in the in some varieties like hungry king which is also an opv or the eight line variety that our farmers do or the colorful names that we've seen you'll find that the number of rows tends to be around eight six to eight and then the number of uh the length of the cup as well tends to be shorter so it tends to produce less grain when we are talking about farming being a business where you need to push in terms of the grain that you get which comes from the huge components that that also include the number of rows of the plants the size of the cob and also the the weight of the grain that you're also going to get so the hybrid seeds came in and it outweighed the opvc in terms of these characteristics then we also saw that over time there was the development of problematic diseases like your gray leaf spots you find like mainstream virus and all those so in those land race varieties or pv varieties there was not much that could be done to safeguard the grain from from the challenges that were caused by these new diseases and new strains of diseases that might have been existing before but with the hybrid seed you are able to introduce new genes that you are going to say because of this particular gene we are now self-guided against this problem because of this gene we are now safeguarded against gray leaf spots so now we have hybrid seeds that is resistant which means it will not be affected by grain spots it will not be affected by leaf rust if it's leaf rust some whatever problematic diseases might exist so hybrid seeds have resistance and tolerance to problematic diseases that the op v seed might not have so um you are seeing that the opv sit so far it might have lower use it might be susceptible to diseases it might also not be drought tolerant because when it was developed climate change had already started the climate has been changing for like it always changes but the rate at which it's changing now was not the same as what happened when those varieties we were failed so you find that uh the hybrid seed is able to withstand long periods of dry spells challenges that come with climate change falling in the fields from wind excess wind or excess rain more than what the opvc will do then moving from the opv seat i think uh concurrently i've also mentioned what the hybrid they are also doing their cropping there are varieties that mature very early 90 to 120 days there are varieties that take 115 days there will be varieties that take longer in the field but also giving higher yields like uh maybe the late maturing varieties that will give 160 to 150 260 days but giving very high yields so there are options with hybrid seeds that don't exist with opg seeds because with opv it's only one seed the the huge potential is the same no matter what you do no matter what you increase even with soil analysis and the good agronomic practices we were mentioning you are unable to reach a certain level there is a there is a ceiling to what you can do with your opv but with hybrids there are a lot of options then moving away from that uh so that i don't over damaging the crop and it becomes cheaper for them increasing then on their bottom line which is the yields because profitability is what you are looking for since farming is also a business even at maybe were not able to do if you're going to be applying a chemical that was going to also affect the crop but affecting all the other weeds like your glyphosate which is a herbicide if you're going
